header.title: Fragments of the Cestes by Julius Africanus: A Critical Edition and Translation

central_thesis: Julius Africanus' 'Cestes' is an encyclopedic work that integrates military strategy, agriculture, medicine, and diverse esoteric practices to provide practical advantages across various domains, particularly in warfare. It reveals the prevalent blending of 'magic' with practical concerns in the ancient world, often under the rubric of 'curiosities' or 'sciences'. This critical edition compiles and analyzes extant fragments, highlighting their transmission and authenticity.

structure_content.summary: Details methods for debilitating enemies beyond direct combat, including the use of pestilence (concoctions from pentagones, euphorbe-myrte in water), poisoned food and drink (lime in wine), and psychological warfare through magical preparations and animal-derived toxins.
Describes the use of 'stones from rooster gizzards' as amulets for soldiers to gain valor and ensure victory in battle, emphasizing a form of sympathetic or talismanic magic.
Outlines a healing method involving a 'plaquette' (small plate) with specific inscribed signs from a pentagone, suggesting talismanic application for recovery.

structure_content.chapter_title: Pour les blessures produites par le fer (I, 5)
structure_content.summary: Presents a ritualistic healing technique for iron wounds: greasing the weapon, chanting 'tata' thrice, spitting, and applying a Latin magical formula transcribed from a pentagone.

structure_content.chapter_title: Pour empêcher un cheval de hennir (I, 7)
structure_content.summary: Details magical methods to silence horses, involving inscriptions of specific Greek letters (phi and digamma) within a pentagone, indicating a form of talismanic control.

structure_content.chapter_title: Pour empêcher un cheval de prendre peur (I, 9)
structure_content.summary: Instructs on attaching a piece of a live-cut beast's tail, inscribed with specific signs from a pentagone, to a horse's right ear to prevent it from panicking, an example of sympathetic and talismanic magic.

Discusses a stratagem involving flutes, but also introduces a 'drogue plus active than prayer' with signs from a pentagone, to be administered via syringes to induce fear in enemy horses through magical means.
Includes poetic allusions to Sleep as a deity and practical instructions for inducing or preventing sleep, such as wearing an amulet made from a 'winged animal' to maintain wakefulness.

Mentions Scythian arrow-poisoning and a protective magical inscription ('abbas') on tin, worn as an amulet against scorpion bites. Also includes an anecdote of Bardesanes using arrows to 'draw' on a shield, blurring lines between art and magic.

A detailed necromantic ritual involving animal sacrifice (blood poured into a pit) and invocations of a diverse pantheon including Greek (Hermes, Zeus Infernal, Hecate, Hades, Helios Titan), Egyptian (Anubis, Phtah, Phrè, Nephtô), and possibly Jewish (Iaveh) deities, alongside esoteric entities like Abraxas, for divination or assistance.
Describes sympathetic magical techniques for sex determination of foals, specifying that mating horses facing the rising sun would produce males, while facing the setting moon would produce females.

structure_content.chapter_title: Pour obtenir sans fatigue de nombreuses saillies (III, 5)
structure_content.summary: Provides an aphrodisiac recipe involving the consumption of skink meat mixed into wine, intended to enhance fertility and sexual vigor in animals.

structure_content.chapter_title: Excellente recette pour favoriser la fécondation (III, 6)
structure_content.summary: Outlines an amuletic practice using the polygonum plant to promote fertility, with the plant's posture determining the sex of the desired offspring (vertical for male, spreading for female).

structure_content.chapter_title: Pour avoir du lait à profusion (III, 7)
structure_content.summary: Describes the use of a 'galactite stone' as a talisman, tied around animal mammaries, to stimulate abundant milk production.
Details a sympathetic magical practice using remora fish, preserved in salt, as a remedy to prevent abortions and aid conception in animals.

structure_content.chapter_title: Sur les tumeurs, les verrues et les acrochordons (III, 17)
structure_content.summary: Describes remedies for skin ailments and includes a peculiar method for detecting thieves: using the tongue of a frog, preserved in salt.
Recommends a preventative measure against poisons and scorpion bites, involving herbs (rue, nuts, dried figs, salt) and an inscribed tin amulet with the word 'abbas' worn around the neck.

structure_content.chapter_title: Pour que le bétail ne soit pas atteint par le souffle d'un crapaud (III, 33)
structure_content.summary: Suggests lighting fires in stables to ward off harmful emanations from toads concealed in dark places, based on the belief that toads fear fire, acting as a protective magic.
A talismanic remedy where the right testicle of a swan, worn as an amulet, is believed to cure specific animal diseases.

structure_content.chapter_title: Moyen d'effacer les marques des chevaux (III, 36)
structure_content.summary: Instructions for cosmetically or magically altering horse coats, including removing old brands and creating panther-like spots using heated irons, reflecting a form of magical transformation or disguise.

A lengthy summary by Psellos detailing Africanus' work on diverse magical applications: procreation magic (sex determination via animal blood), milk production, sterility amulets (frog brains), easy childbirth (jet stone), fertility mixtures, hemostatics (mulberry branches), hair dyeing, voice improvement, gold oxidation (mad dog saliva), antidotes for bites, scorpion remedies, thief detection (frog tongues), inducing physiological functions (defecation, urination, laughter), artificial fertility, preventing sterility, preventing drunkenness (moonstone), and love-inducing formulas (gorgonion).
Mentions Africanus' prescription of a plaster called 'stysia' applied to the thumb and heel to induce erection, classifying it as sexual magic.

key_concepts.definition: An encyclopedic work by Julius Africanus, covering a wide array of subjects from military tactics, agriculture, and medicine to various forms of magic and esoteric practices, intended to provide practical advantages in diverse life domains.

Geometric figures serving as templates for magical inscriptions, amulets, and ritual diagrams. These are mentioned in conjunction with remedies and tactical advice, indicating their role in active magical workings and talisman creation within Africanus' system.

A pervasive principle in Africanus' work, based on the belief that objects or beings can influence others through resemblance or previous contact. Examples include using animal body parts for related effects (e.g., rooster gizzard stones for valor, swallow gizzards for eye healing, animal blood for sex determination).

The creation and use of inscribed or consecrated objects, often animal parts or plaques, worn or applied to exert influence. Specific examples include inscribed plaques from pentagones, animal testicles as amulets, and inscribed tin for protection against venomous bites.

Structured actions, chants, and applications of specific substances or objects to achieve a magical outcome. This includes precise sequences for healing wounds, invoking deities, or preparing potent compounds.

The deliberate deployment of toxic substances derived from plants, animals, or minerals for military advantage, often mixed into enemy food and water supplies, and sometimes involving esoteric preparations linked to astrological or symbolic figures.

A ritual practice aimed at invoking the dead, typically for divinatory purposes or to gain knowledge or assistance. Africanus describes a specific ritual involving animal sacrifice and a diverse pantheon of deities.

The practice of discerning hidden knowledge or future events through observation of animal behavior (e.g., horses predicting events) or the characteristics of objects, and the use of specific rituals or preparations to enhance intuitive or prophetic abilities.

practical_system.description: The Cestes detail an eclectic practical system for achieving various outcomes, from battlefield advantage to animal husbandry and personal well-being, predominantly through sympathetic, talismanic, and ritual magic. The system emphasizes specific ingredients (herbal, animal, mineral), precise measurements, and ritual actions like chanting, spitting, and gestures. A core element involves the use of 'pentagones' or 'hexagones' as templates for inscribing magical signs and formulae, which are then applied as amulets or integrated into larger rituals.
tools: Pentagones/Hexagones: Geometric diagrams for inscribing magical signs and formulae.
Bronze Stylus: Used for precise inscription on amulets or magical tools.
Animal Parts: Rooster gizzard stones, wolf canines, swallow gizzards, hedgehog liver, swan testicles, serpent skin, frog brains/tongues, hare/goose blood.
Herbal/Mineral Ingredients: Euphorbe-myrte, lime, parieta.ria, coqueret root, myrrh, aristolochia, gentian, laurel, rue, asphodel, souchet, citron fruit, alum, lead, honey, wine, sea algae, etc.
Dioptre: A geometric instrument for measuring distances, also possibly used in conjunction with magical diagrams (I, 15).
Ceramic/Metal Vessels: For preparing magical concoctions and storing ingredients (I, 2).
Syringes: For administering liquid magical preparations (I, 11).
rituals: Healing Iron Wounds: Grease the offending weapon, chant 'tata' thrice, spit, and apply a Latin formula inscribed within a pentagone to the wound (I, 5).
Preventing Horse Fear: Attach a portion of a beast's tail, cut from a living animal and inscribed with specific signs from a pentagone, to the horse's right ear (I, 9).

Necromantic Invocation: Perform animal sacrifice by bleeding into a pit, then invoke a diverse pantheon of Greek, Egyptian, and possibly Jewish deities (e.g., Anubis, Hermes, Zeus Infernal, Hecate, Iaveh, Abraxas) to gain information or assistance (V, 1).
Sex Determination for Foals: Initiate horse mating while the animals face the rising sun to produce male offspring, or face the setting moon for females (III, 3).
Inducing Fertility/Sailles: Administer skink meat in wine as an aphrodisiac (III, 5).
Promoting Fertility (animals): Use a polygonum plant as an amulet; if growing vertically, it ensures a male foal; if spreading, a female foal (III, 6).
Enhancing Lactation: Apply a 'galactite stone' as a talisman to animal mammaries to increase milk production (III, 7).
Preventing Abortion: Utilize remora fish preserved in salt as a sympathetic remedy to avert miscarriages (III, 8).
Detecting Thieves: Historically, frog tongues were used for this purpose (IX, 1, Psellos).
Inducing Erection: Apply a plaster called 'stysia' to the thumb and heel (IX, 6, Fulgence).
Inflicting Pestilence: Prepare concoctions from specific animals (from pentagones) or plants (e.g., euphorbe-myrte) and introduce them into enemy water or food sources (I, 2).
Protective Magic Against Toads: Light fires in stables to repel harmful emanations from hidden toads (III, 33).

relevant_quotes.text: C'est suivant la raison, l'usage, le destin ou le hasard que se produisent les issues des événements: progrès et ruines, altérations et guérisons. Et il est précieux de connaître chacun de ces effets, lorsque de leur ensemble on obtient une récolte d'avantages variés: traitement des maladies, histoire secrète, beauté d'un récit.

Pour celui qui souffrira d'une blessure produite par le fer, voici un remède à sa douleur. Il convient de graisser le fer qui a fait le mal et d'en frapper la plaie. Prononçons ensuite par trois fois « tata » et, tout en crachant, une formule latine qui est inscrite dans le pentagone représenté sous le n° 5, contre les signes de la lichanos chromatique, alpha renversé portant un trait par derrière et gamma retourné portant 2 traits par derrière.

« Entends-moi, Anubis, protecteur bienveillant, puissant générateur... Viens, Hermès, ravisseur, à moi, Zeus infernal, aux beaux cheveux bouclés; ratifiez mes vœux, exaucez ma prière. À moi, Hadès et Terre, et toi, Hélios Titan, à la flamme éternelle. Venez aussi Iaveh, Phtah, Phrè, soutien des lois, Nephtô très honoré, très riche Ablanathô, à la tête d'ibis, qui portes à la ceinture un serpent de feu et retournes la terre, Abraxas, au nom cosmique en tout lieu chanté, divinité qui fait tourner l'axe du monde et le chœur des étoiles et les froides lumières que lancent les deux Ourses. Viens aussi Phrèn, qui,...»

Si l'on veut voir naître un mâle, il faut tourner les chevaux vers le levant, de façon qu'ils regardent le soleil pendant la saillie. Le couchant engendre les femelles, comme l'expose l'éleveur Maurus.
«J'ai un esprit insatiable pour toute espèce de savoir; je voudrais ne rien ignorer et je désirerais connaître même les entrailles de la terre».

critical_analysis.relevance: Julius Africanus' 'Cestes' is a highly relevant work for the study of Western Esotericism, as it demonstrates the practical application of magical principles within a broader encyclopedic context during Late Antiquity. It showcases a syncretic blend of Greek, Roman, Egyptian, and possibly Jewish esoteric traditions, revealing how magical thought was integrated into pragmatic concerns such as military strategy, medicine, and agriculture. The text predates many formal grimoire traditions but shares foundational elements like sympathetic magic, talismanic creation, and ritualized actions. Its inclusion of specific diagrams (pentagones), animal parts, and planetary/celestial influences provides valuable insight into the operative mechanics of ancient magic, illustrating a worldview where the 'occult' and 'scientific' were often intertwined, categorized as 'curiosities' or advanced knowledge. The critical edition itself is crucial for understanding the complex textual transmission of such esoteric knowledge.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience for 'Cestes' would have been ancient practitioners, including military commanders, agriculturalists, healers, and nascent magicians seeking practical advantages in their respective fields. For this critical edition, the audience expands to modern scholars of Western Esotericism, historians of ancient science and magic, classicists, and practitioners of contemporary magical traditions interested in the historical roots and practical methodologies of ancient operative magic.
